page.title: 04TYNEMOUTH LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: Tynemouth has the ruins of a Castle and a Priory both occupying the same headland overloking the mouth of the {River Tyne }. {Tynemouth Castle} The Castle began life in about the year 650 as a wall and gate into the Benedictine monastery, and steadily grew in importance as a fortress because of its position not too far from the Scottish border and at the mouth of the River Tyne. The site has continued to be of great military importance right up to modern times. Gun positions used in World War II (1939-1945) can still be seen. The gatehouse was occupied by the armed forces until 1936 when it was gutted by fire. Since 1960 it has been a major attraction for tourism.
